nological routes to reduce energy system emissions (see Section 6.6). Here we
discuss three of these: (1) decarbonizing primary energy and electricity generation, (2) switching to
electricity, bioenergy, hydrogen, and other fuels produced from low
energy use through improvement of efficiency and conservation. CDR is discussed in Section 6.7.1.X;
Fossil fuel transitions are discussed in Section 6.7.4.
Decarbonizing Primary Energy and Electricity Generation.

). Decarbonizing electricity generation, in tandem with increasing use of electricity
term strategy for limiting warming. The increase in low
carbon electricity will occur while electricity demand grows substantially. Studies have projected that
global electricity demand will roughly double by 20
50 and quadruple to quintuple by 2100 irrespective
(Bauer et al. 2017; Luderer et al. 2017; I
Renewable energy, especially generation from solar and wind, is likely to have an important role in
carbon electricity systems. The contributions of wind and solar electricity will depend on
their levelized costs relative to other op
tions, integration costs, system value, and the ability to integrate
variable resources into the grid (Section 6.6). Electric sector technology mixes will vary by region but
such as hydropower, nuclear power, fos
, energy storage resources, and geothermal energy, among others.

n for longer durations, though deployment of these technologies is typically
